Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This class teaches kinematics and energy conservation, and rotational motion (basically the same as in high school, perhaps a little more in depth), as well as relativity, springs with air resistance, and fluid motion. We were supposed to learn thermodynamics, but ran out of time.
Concepts that go beyond most high school classes include special relativity, fluids, and simple harmonic motion. You also become a better problem solver throughout the experience.
I gained a good knowledge of basic physics, especially for engineering purposes.
Physics: Mechanics (Kinematics, Rotational Dynamics, Relativity, Kepler's Laws), Basic Fluid Mechanics
I gained a good baseline knowledge of Newtonian mechanics and other intro physics topics.
A strong understanding of the basics of physics

This course gave me a deeper insight into the physics I learned in high school, while adding new topics such as fluids and special relativity. Through the problem sets and exams, I developed my problem solving skills, teaching me how to go from initial condition and a set of formulas to the final answer.

This course taught me the different concepts behind mechanics and special relativity with a lot of detail. You learned how to solve physics problems and explain conceptually what should happen or why something is not a paradox conceptually. The course covers all of mechanics, fluids, special relativity and even a bit of thermodynamics and we solve the relevant problems in all of these topics.
I learned about Newtonian physics in dept.

I took AP Physics in high school and had a really intense instructor who loved going above and beyond the curriculum. With that said, I didn't really learn that much new in PHYS 200 until we started with special relativity. The new units were fun to learn, and I definitely learned how to grind out difficult problem sets: there was a lot of that in this course. I am not sure how I would have felt about the problem sets had I not learned at least most of it beforehand.
I developed most of the knowledge necessary to do well in Physics 200.
Lots of new physics principles.
Covered the basic intro physics topics, from mechanics to waves. Not an intensely math-based perspective, but some. Sort of repetitive to a high school physics course.
I developed good study habits and became a better student.

A lot of the content of the course is review if you took AP physics. The new concepts that were covered in depth were the complexities of simple harmonic motion and special relativity. In these sections, as with the rest of the topics, there was a much greater emphasis on the math that proved the equations. Unfortunately the class doesn't really slow down to explain the content, and we learn about the mathematical principles about two weeks before we cover the necessary content in Math 120.
I learned the basics of many fields of calculus-based physics.
I learned a lot of introductory physics in various subjects.

I learned two classes of information, concepts, and techniques in this class. First, I essentially had a repetition of the concepts taught in an introductory physics mechanics course (like AP Physics C Mechanics). This part was fast but had very doable problems. Then, I learned in more depth than I ever had before about new concepts such as special relativity, the wave equation, and more. Essentially, this was introductory physics for students who have already taken the AP test.

This course was very informative, and the material is a good challenge from high school physics. I learned a lot about relativity and simple harmonic motion, and is a good amount of new material for a introductory college course. In this course, I got a feel about

Overall a great course in terms of breadth
Learned a lot about kinematics, dynamics, work and energy, momentum, rotational motion, special relativity, fluids, waves, simple harmonic motion, etc.
Excellent first college physics experience
Problem solving
I gained a deeper understanding of physics concepts by taking this course, and I also got to learn about how calculus can be used in physics problems for the very first time.
I found relevant help outside of class for hard problems and concepts.
Deeper understanding of mechanics.
I learned to understand physics conceptually and to connect it to the math behind it.
I learned mechanics based physics. (motion, simple harmonic motion, fluids, special relativity, gravity, rotation, forces, etc.)
I learned about physics mechanics, special relativity, simple harmonic motion, and waves in this class. I also learned that I am not interested in studying physics in the future.
We learned the fundamentals of kinematics, fluids, gravity, energy, waves, special relativity, and more. We covered a lot of the derivation of the equations for these topics as well.
Developed my knowledge of mechanical physics and space time relativity.
Broad topics in physics and their mathematical derivations
Developed a better foundation in mechanics, waves, and relativity.
A lot of physics.  I really enjoyed the u it on special relativity because I had never seen it before.
I learned about how to do physics with calculus.
I guess I learned a lot of practical applications for multi variable calc and the fundamentals of mechanics with a more rigorous approach than that of a high school AP Physics C class.
I developed my basic physics skills as well as some of my calculus skills, as this course was somewhat calculus-based
Had a great review of kinematics and dynamics, learned a lot about relativity and fluids. Good rotational motion knowledge too.
I learned to work well in a group by attending TA office hours and student group review sessions. I definitely learned a lot about physics.
Physics problem solving skills
Foundational understanding of mechanics, relativity and other physical phenomena. An introduction to calculus-based physics.
This course helped me learn how I should be working for a college course. I have also gained more knowledge about Physics including relativity!

Physics 200 is not a good course. The lectures are boring and nearly useless, focusing solely on deriving equations rather than applying and understanding them. I was shocked at how poorly taught Physics 200 was in comparison to my high school physics courses. We almost never discussed concepts or did practice problems; all we did was trace out the derivations already written up in the book. I went to lecture every day, but I suspect that I could have learned just as much without ever setting foot in lecture. If this course is to improve, lecture needs to be drastically reorganized. Also, the grading of psets and tests was often lazy and opaque, and the two midterms both took almost a month to be handed back. Equation sheets were often late and/or riddled with typos.

Strengths= problem sets allowed students to learn but weren't overwhelming; study halls were necessary and allowed you to meet other kids in the class
Weaknesses= lectures basically just repeated the textbook information with no application to other scenarios

Physics is so fascinating and Sarah makes it even more fascinating. The content covered is very interesting - I wish we did more specific spacetime material. I think some of the derivations even in the Shankar part were a little unclear - it would be nice if Sarah could throw in multivariable calc-based tidbits, just connecting the concepts a little (for example conservative forces and integrating over a pathway) or maybe a little differential equations. Kids who understand will be really happy because it will connect everything we're learning. Sarah is such an enthusiastic teacher and I love learning from her. Her physics news segments are very interesting. Hoping we will go over thermo during second semester.

Strengths: The teacher was a fun person and made it interesting to listen to the lecture.

Weaknesses: The topics were not covered well at all, and it felt like the only way I learned in the course was by reading the textbook.
Great intro physics course, gives you the basics and the mathematical background required is not that bad.

In the nature of the course, it goes very quickly and unfortunately there isnt a lot of time to go more in depth on the topics. The course would definitely be improved with more practice problems and hands-on examples.

Professor Demers is very enthusiastic and brings a lot of energy to the classroom! The course was pretty well organized, although some of the lectures dragged on longer than they needed to. Also, office hours could have been clearer and more accessible.
I really enjoyed this course. We covered the right amount of material with the right level of rigor. I wish the math were a little more sound.

The course was great. I had some physics experience in high school, so the more theoretical approach to the material did not bother me. I thought the study halls were very helpful for working through the problem sets, which were challenging but gave important insight into the material covered in lecture.  I would improve the grading of the exams: 1. it took too long to get them back and 2. I don't think there were useful comments to help me understand what I did wrong, so I needed to talk to the professor or TA's afterwards.

The course is strong in developing you to think through physics concepts and explain why different things happen or what should happen. The way we go through the material can be a bit too fast at times, but enough resources are out there (Shankar's lecture videos or his textbook) to reinforce learning as long as you put enough time into understanding the material.
I felt that this course was poorly constructed. Most of the learning had to be done on my own and the problem sets were very challenging.

I actually really liked the study-hall set up for doing problem sets. I spent a lot of time at the study halls and made a lot of friends. It was also where I did most of my learning. I am not sure if that is a strength or a weakness, but I definitely found like lecture never really gave me the insights I needed to tackle the problems, and study halls where were I made the biggest strides.
We didn't have time to cover all of the material
Strength is its combination of new and old material as compared to AP physics C

Material is interesting, problem sets reasonable, tests fair. I think the study halls could have been better organized, often it was hard to find the TA's since it was so crowded, and it was a stressful environment in which to try to strengthen understanding of the material. Also, twice I went to office hours and couldn't find the TA.

Professor Demers is a fantastic person who is obviously passionate about her field. The only problem lies in the fact that she's not studying mechanics. Thus she was not engaged with the course material and that made the structure of her lectures haphazard and hard to follow.
It was taught very well, but could've been a bit better organized.

The main strengths of this course were that the content was taught at a happy medium level. It was not too slow for most of the class that is already well versed in mechanics, but it was also not too fast or new to confuse students who needed a refresher. It is perfect for a student that needs to take introductory physics for a major requirement but would be bored retaking the AP class (which seems to be what 180 is). Professor Demers was very interested in teaching and explaining the more novel concepts in the class, such as relativity, which is where the class really shined.

The are no solid weaknesses in the class, but it seemed like the combined TF sessions/office hours were a little difficult to navigate when it was crowded. Aside from this, the class was effective in its goals.

The material is very well balanced and is structured very well. It is also a good amount of work, with a great amount of office hours and lectures per week.
I wish that this course, especially given that it is a large lecture course, had a small section that people were able to go to in order to review the material taught during the lecture. Also, the feedback for our problem sets was very varied, and often did not match up with the answer key.

Strong in terms of breadth of topics covered
Weak in terms of lack of depth when studying certain topics (but this is by necessity because only so much can be covered in a semester)
Can't see any feasible way in which this could be improved

Sarah is a great lecturer. She's very aware of how the class is responding to the material and her excitement over the material keeps things interesting. The physics study halls really need improving as far as location times and organization. Because of that office hours and reviews are a must if you're struggling with the material. The TAs were fine, some better than others, but they aren't very familiar with the particular methods that Shankar uses in the textbook.

Strength: interesting

Weakness: disorganized

The strengths of this course are that it provides a comprehensive overview over multiple fields of physics, and this course could be improved by focusing more on understanding the derivations of equations in the problem sets.
Sometimes lecture did not give us all the tools needed to solve all the problems.

Confusing proofs and occasionally disorganized lectures, but very engagingly taught. However, new problem sets were often released late, and the content they covered wasn't taught until very soon before they were due.
This course is great because it provides a deep understanding of the concepts and it also gives the students the opportunity to use the concepts in practical situations.

I thought the problem sets were overall very helpful and it was a very reasonable workload.  I think that the lectures could be improved a little bit by doing a lot more example problems instead of concept explanation (good but sometimes hard to follow). I also think the physics study halls all together with other physics courses wasn't as helpful.  If there were more TA's and maybe a separate space for group study that would be helpful.
The strengths include the teacher and her lectures. She organized the TAs and peer tutors well.

The course covered relevant material, but as the semester continued, the professor's explanations seemed to deteriorate. I was quite pleased with her teaching in the first half of the semester, but I became more and more confused as the semester progressed. Additionally, the TA's availability also seemed to diminish as we neared the time for exams, which was both frustrating and unhelpful.

Strengths: it was a good overview of the main topics of physics, the study halls were very helpful, the tests were very fair
Weaknesses: the professor isnt great, it was pretty much straight from the textbook
The material taught in class is more conceptual, so it is difficult to apply to the problem sets.

Weakness: needs more example/practice problems. Often feels like professor is just copying down the textbook.
Strength: study halls were helpful.
The level of difficulty of the course varied quite a bit, as well as the difficulty of the problem sets.

This course has interesting topics and the teacher was very invested in the students. Sometimes, the psets were way too hard and did not accurately reflect what we had learned so even if you did the pset, you felt as if you hadn't learned as much or didn't know as much as you really do. Thankfully the problem help sessions were extremely helpful. I think for next time some of the lecture should be dedicated to solving example problems/ giving us tools to solve some problems on the psets.
The lectures were good, but the last couple werent as good as the others.  The psets were alright.  The study halls were very helpful.

Strengths: Professor Demers is a great prof.
Weaknesses: the lectures basically follow the book exactly which in some ways is nice but also left me feeling like certain elements were very repetitive if you were reading along.
The course was a good overview of physics. However, I didnt like how we mostly did proofs in class. I think it would have been more beneficial to do more practice problems.

Lectures were good, Sarah explained things well and used examples. Sometimes she didnt use enough examples, but was very open and upfront about student feedback which helped correct that. Psets were great and manageable and thorough, but sometimes help hours were  disorganized. TAs werent there once.
My strengths were understanding of the material and ability to complete problem sets independently. My main weakness was attention to detail and I made lots of errors because of this.
Lectures were sometimes confusing, got a little behind schedule. Problem sets were well done and interesting.

Very engaging and clear lectures. Shankar's textbook was also great and a pleasure to read. Unfortunately, towards the end, we got off-sync with the syllabus, resulting in us not covering as much material as originally planned.

Covers a good range of material and all the relevant topics to form a basis for more physics and engineering related courses. PSETs were well made and manageable. Study halls were useful and well timed throughout the week. 
Biggest issue with the course was the accompanying textbook - Fundamentals of Physics by R. Shankar. The book is entertaining and easy to read - but that's not the point of a physics textbook. It reads like a story or narrative, and is not helpful for looking up information and concepts, or as a reference. It was novel in the beginning but by the end it was irritating to go through pages of drivel to get to a single derivation, and even then there were digressions.

I felt I was a bit behind at the beginning of the year (more advanced math/physics classes not offered at my high school) and the class was a bit fast. However, I felt that instead of that being a reason why I wasn't doing so hot in the course, it became an excuse for me and that severely affected my performance and happiness in the class.
Absolutely not. The class was one of my worst at Yale so far. The instructor seemed to put very little effort into teaching or grading. Although I love physics, I did not enjoy this class.

I'd definitely recommend this course over 180, even if you aren't that confident in your physics skills. This class has less busy work and gets down to business. It's also really interesting to learn about special relativity, which is arguably the coolest part of intro physics.
Yes, I would. Professor Demers is absolutely fantastic and makes the class enjoyable no matter your background.

Yes! If you've taken physics before, this is really interesting. I learned stuff that I didn't learn in AP physics at a higher intellectual level, and the psets really made me think without being busywork at all. Go to study halls - Emma was an incredibly helpful TA and it was fun to work with other students. I wasn't initially sure whether to take this class or 180 and I'm so happy I took this class - the concepts are way more interesting and the work is way more rewarding. Sarah is an inspiring teacher. The end of the semester was a little scattered but Shankar's videos are really good supplements for class.
I mean, if you already know physics, then this class will be fine because the tests are easy. Otherwise, it's going to be an difficult time because the material was not explained well at all.
Ya
Yes, it's a great introductory course. If you're a physics major, do this. 260 and 180 are too masochistic.
I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to someone who doesn't need it as a prerequisite, but as far as I can tell it is definitely the best of the intro physics tracks!
Yes, if you have some physics experience from high school and have a good math background, I would recommend this over PHYS 180. Roughly the same material, but taught in a unique way I think.

I would recommend this course to another student because this class really gives you a deep understanding of physics and is more interesting than some of the other introductory physics classes since it goes deeper into the concepts to ensure you can do more than just solve problems, but that you can also understand conceptually why different things occur.
Not necessarily. This course was very challenging and confusing at times. The textbook was mediocre and the lectures were not that informative.

If you have to take physics, you have to take physics. I took this class having taken an intense AP Physics experience in HS, and looking back on it, I'm not sure if I would have made the same decision. I didn't learn much until the first midterm. To be fair, it wasn't like the problem sets were easy, it just felt silly to be putting so much effort into a class that I felt like I had learned a decent amount of last year. The exams were very fair, and I did fine in the class, it's just not THAT far beyond the AP curriculum, at least as it was taught in my high school.
I would if they enjoyed physics
Yes but would inform them it is a challenge.

This is a fine intro Physics course. I took this because I felt 260 would be too difficult, but wanted to do special relativity, which 180 does not teach. I also was hoping for some more math, but I wouldn't say it was very mathematically rigorous. It wasn't an overwhelming class and I felt like I got a good overview of foundational physics topics and ways of thinking.

You have to be dedicated to teaching yourself outside of class if you want to understand the content in depth. There were many times when I was only able to learn the material via online resources. Shankar's textbook is helpful, but is confusing to follow in many instances. Some of the TAs are very helpful. Go to their office hours.
I would. It was an engaging and interesting introduction to calculus-based physics.
Sure. If you're interested in physics and you think this is the right level for you, then why not?

To make it very simple, choose to take Physics 200 over Physics 170/180/200/260 if you need to take an introductory physics course for some requirement or because you want to, and if you also are confident in your grasp of mechanics at the AP level, want to do much less tedious work than in 180, want to learn some new concepts, but don't want it taking up all of your time (like 260 would). This is the happy medium introductory physics course in terms of complexity, but also had far less work (based on my discussions with other students in other classes) than the other classes, especially compared to 180. Problem sets in 200 are very straightforward and usually only take up one page  you don't need to read paragraphs on paragraphs to answer a simple mechanics question. In the end, it is also an enjoyable, interesting, and well-taught course with some new ideas to learn.
Not unless they were a physics major and required to take it. I believe that the material of the course is perfect, but the instruction could be a little more helpful.

I'd recommend this course to another student. Great broad and expansive first intro to college physics topics at a somewhat mathematical level
Students with advanced preparation in math can fill in the gaps to make the material even more intuitive
Take this over 260 if you're unsure between the two, I shopped 260 and had to level change because I thought I was ready but clearly was not
200 is challenging in and of itself, be cautious and take it instead of 260
Only if required by a major.
No, disorganized and didn't learn much

I would in fact recommend this course to another student because there are countless resources to facilitate all types of learning styles, from online lectures to a comprehensive textbook, and this is a good course to develop a strong physics foundation.
I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in physics and excited to be challenged.
Important if going forward in physics. Prof is very engaging.
Yes, this course provides a wide range of physics concepts and it also provides a deep analysis of each concept.
Yes, I think it's a good class for intro physics sequence, especially if you don't want to be in 180 and like physics/calc a little more, but don't want to do th 260 sequence.
I would recommend this course to others. It was well taught and had a lot of support between the students and the TAs.

I would recommend this course, but ONLY if it is a requirement. If you took AP Physics in high school, only take this course if you feel confident with the material. If there is any doubt, it is probably better to take 180.
If you want an overview of physics that covers a lot of topics fairly well, then yes
If youre interested in a semi challenging physics class yes
If you need it as a prerequisite, then yes
Yes I would I thought it was a fabulous class that will only get better as Professor Demers teaches it more and more.
I would recommend to someone that has a good handle of the basics of physics and calculus wanting to learn more about how the two are related.

I would recommend this to someone who really likes physics but isnt so experienced or mathematically inclined as a 260 student. It really does cover the important topics in an effective way. It is deceptively challenging though. I thought the the class was rather easy, but it ended up being my lowest grade of the classes I took this semester. I would say, dont forget that physics problems involve a great amount of attention to detail
I would recommend this course to anyone who was taking physics because it was a good overview of the basic concepts.

I took this class for a science credit and because I always liked physics and wanted to learn relativity. The relativity unit was pretty short, but overall I enjoyed the class and got a good foundational knowledge of physics, reinforced by solidly challenging problems in the manageable psets. Sarah is a great lecturer though sometimes disorganized, but shes very great about student feedback. All exams were fair and not bad.

Yes. This class was a great introduction to college physics that quickly summarized what was learned in high school but forced us to relearn the material in a way that demanded a mathematical understanding of why things are the way they are rather than just memorizing formulas.
I would recommend this course. Even though this class moves faster than PHYS 180, I think its worth it in order to learn about other concepts, especially relativity.

Yes, if you have had prior experience with physics in high school (AP/IB Physics, etc). It can be hard to follow at times but when it is interesting, it is REALLY interesting. It is very good in exposing you to the various topics of physics. It presents a good intellectual challenge without being insanely hard.
Would definitely recommend. It's a great introduction to college physics and Prof. Sarah Demers was a dream to learn from. Always helpful and kept the class alive (which was a heavy task at times).
